name: Thou Shalt Not Quiz | Musicals | 10 Questions

questions.text: Who wrote the music and lyrics for the show?
questions.explanation:
Harry Connick, Jr.

	Connick later recorded some songs from the show on his two-disc CD "Harry on Broadway: Act One". Norbert Leo Butz was in the show, but he didn't write the lyrics or music.

questions.text: Which character sings "Oh! Ain't That Sweet"?
questions.explanation:
Camille Raquin.

	Camille Raquin was originally played by Norbert Leo Butz, who was nominated for a Tony Award for his acting. He later won a Tony for his turn as Freddy Benson in "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels".

questions.text: Craig Bierko originated the role of Sanctify Sam.
questions.explanation:
False.

	Bierko originated the role of Laurent LeClaire. Sanctify Sam was originally played by Ted L. Levy, who also played other roles in the show. Sanctify Sam sings "Won't You Sanctify".

Sovereign.

	"Sovereign Lover" is sung by Busker, Laurent, Therese and the ensemble. Busker was originally played by Ted L. Levy and Therese was originally played by Kate Levering.

questions.text: Camille sings "I've Got my Eye On You" with his mother.
questions.explanation:
True.

	Madame Raquin is an overbearing mother. Debra Monk originated the role. She has also been seen in "Company", "Assassins" and "Steel Pier".

He drowns.

	Laurent and Therese become lovers, and Laurent kills Camille by pushing him over the side of a rowboat. After waiting a year, Laurent marries Therese himself, and they believe they shall have a happy marriage.

questions.text: What does Laurent do for a living?
questions.explanation:
He is a pianist.

	Laurent was a jazz pianist before he went off to serve in World War II, and he takes up his old job when he returns from the war. He runs into his old friend Camille and falls in love with Camille's wife.

questions.text: "Thou Shalt Not" is based on a book by this author.
questions.explanation:
Emile Zola.

	Emile Zola lived from 1840 to 1902 and wrote many books. He lived in Paris and was an outspoken critic of Napoleon III. He became so outspoken that he once had to flee to England!

questions.text: Who directed the original production of "Thou Shalt Not"?
questions.explanation:
Susan Stroman.

	Susan Stroman has also directed such musicals as "The Producers" and "The Music Man". She also choreographed both shows, and won a Tony Award for directing "The Producers".

questions.text: At which theater did the show originally play?
questions.explanation:
Plymouth Theatre.

	"Thou Shalt Not" opened on October 25, 2001 and closed on January 6, 2002 at the Plymouth Theatre on Broadway. Other shows that have played there include "Brooklyn" and "Taboo". It was renamed the Gerald Schoenfeld Theatre in 2005.
